channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Coronavirus News Updates and Full Analysis
item.description: President Trump pushes to reopen schools, and criticizes Dr. Fauci’s warnings about moving too quickly. The administration weighs extending some border restrictions indefinitely.

item.title: Coronavirus Lockdowns: Businesses Turn to Armed Defiance
item.description: Armed militia-style protesters have helped businesses across Texas defy coronavirus lockdowns and reopen. Protesters say they are enforcing the Constitution.
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez and David Montgomery
item.media:credit: Eli Hartman/Odessa American, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An armed protester provided support to the owner of a bar in Odessa, Texas, which reopened last week in defiance of an order that it remain shut.

item.title: Wisconsin Supreme Court Says Coronavirus Shutdown Is Overreach
item.description: The decision, by a 4-to-3 majority, was a high-profile challenge of the emergency authority of a statewide official during the coronavirus pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: A protest against the coronavirus shutdown in front of the State Capitol in Madison, Wis., in late April.

item.title: Coronavirus Canceled County Fairs. Now Children Show Their Cows and Sheep Virtually.
item.description: The coronavirus has thwarted summertime fairs, a tradition for youngsters who work on farms all year for their moment in the ring.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey
item.media:description: Emma Helsinger, 9, has entered virtual shows in Ohio but said she was disappointed she did not get to show off her pigs in the ring.

item.title: Asian Markets Fall on Fears of Slow Pandemic Recovery: Live Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: A quiet business building in Tokyo, on Thursday.

item.title: Coronavirus World Updates
item.description: The United Nations is warning of new risks to children and a subsequent plague of mental illness. And governments are noting the unintended consequences of lockdowns and other restrictions.
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral in São Paulo, Brazil, for José Veracruz, who died after contracting the coronavirus. Brazil’s death toll has surpassed 13,000.

item.title: TikTok Broke Privacy Promises, Children’s Groups Say
item.description: Twenty consumer groups said the video app had failed to make some changes it agreed to carry out last year to settle federal charges.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.media:description: TikTok is under scrutiny by consumer groups.

item.title: Judge in Flynn Case Renowned for His Independent Streak
item.description: U.S. District Court Judge Emmet Sullivan will hear a challenge to the Justice Department’s surprise move to drop charges against President Trump’s former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Judge Emmet G. Sullivan was first appointed to the bench by President Ronald Reagan.

item.title: Trump Picks Ex-Drug Company Executive to Lead Accelerated Coronavirus Vaccine Effort
item.description: The chief operating officer will be an Army general who specializes in logistics.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority
item.media:description: Moncef Slaoui before the House Oversight and Government Reform committee hearing on the diabetes drug Avandia in 2007.

item.title: Republicans Release Names of Obama-Era Officials in ‘Unmaskings’ That Revealed Flynn
item.description: The moves prompted accusations that President Trump’s allies were disclosing the information for his political benefit.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department moved last week to drop a false-statements criminal case against Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s first national security adviser.

item.title: Michael Flynn Case: Judge Appoints Outsider to Take On Justice Dept.
item.description: A retired judge will also examine whether the former national security adviser committed perjury.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s first national security adviser, in 2017 in Washington.

item.title: Charges Against Former Michigan State President Are Dismissed
item.description: A judge said prosecutors had failed to prove that Lou Anna K. Simon knew of sexual abuse committed by Dr. Lawrence G. Nassar when he was employed by the university.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:description: Lou Anna K. Simon, a former president of Michigan State University, in 2018.

item.title: New Inflammatory Condition in Children Probably Linked to Coronavirus, Study Finds
item.description: Researchers compared 10 cases in Italy with previous cases of a similar childhood illness, Kawasaki disease. The rate of the new cases was much higher, and the conditions were more serious.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:description: Medical staff tending to a coronavirus patient in the I.C.U. of the Papa Giovanni XXIII Hospital in Bergamo, Italy. The hospital’s pediatric center saw 10 cases of the inflammatory condition in just two months.

item.title: Running Your First Race Indoors
item.description: Here’s what life is like for a teacher who’s making her first run for office amid the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

item.title: Ex-F.B.I. Official Is Said to Undercut Justice Dept. Effort to Drop Flynn Case
item.description: Prosecutors questioned a former F.B.I. official whose notes were used to buttress their motion to dismiss the charge against the president’s first national security adviser.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman and Katie Benner
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Bill Priestap, a former top F.B.I. official, played a central role in the agency’s 2016 investigation into Russia’s efforts to interfere in the presidential election.

item.title: Utah Lowers Penalty for Polygamy, No Longer a Felony
item.description: An amendment that went into effect this week allows polygamy to be punished as an infraction in some cases, but it remains a felony if force, threats or other abuses are involved.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: A group of pro-polygamy demonstrators at the Utah State Capitol in Salt Lake City in 2017.

item.title: Small-Business Loan Deadline Poses Test for Mnuchin
item.description: The Treasury Secretary has given big companies until May 18 to return their Paycheck Protection Program loans or face criminal liability. Many borrowers are rebuffing those demands.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and David McCabe
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin’s threat is likely to set off a wave of new government audits and legal fights over who is entitled to aid money.

item.title: In Bid for Party Unity, Biden Moves Beyond Restoring the Pre-Trump Era
item.description: Trying to win over progressives and aware that the coronavirus crisis is upending the political landscape, Joe Biden is increasingly using the language of systemic disruption.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck and Astead W. Herndon
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has often resisted calls for sweeping societal changes, urging a more incremental approach.

item.title: In Guam, the Aircraft Carrier Roosevelt Is Still Battling the Virus
item.description: A sailor infected with the coronavirus was quickly whisked off the ship, which is docked in Guam as Navy officials prepare for the vessel to deploy.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.media:description: The aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt at sea in March.

item.title: Mike Garcia Wins California 25 in Special Election
item.description: Mike Garcia, who won the endorsement of President Trump, flipped California’s 25th Congressional District after Representative Katie Hill, a Democrat, resigned last year.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:description: Mike Garcia won California’s 25th Congressional District.

item.title: Joel Kupperman, Scarred by Success as a ‘Quiz Kid,’ Dies at 83
item.description: As a philosophy professor in adulthood, he would not speak of the World War II-era radio show (later on TV) that had made him famous and left him embittered.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.media:description: Six-year-old Joel Kupperman as a contestant on the radio show “The Quiz Kids” in 1943. He and other young contestants found nationwide fame answering questions about math, literature, sports and history.

item.title: In a First, Renewable Energy Is Poised to Eclipse Coal in U.S.
item.description: The coronavirus has pushed the coal industry to once-unthinkable lows, and the consequences for climate change are big.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Libby March for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Kintigh Generating Station in Somerset, N.Y., the state’s last coal-burning plant, just before it was shut down in March.

item.title: Supreme Court Seems Ready to Curb ‘Faithless Electors’
item.description: Fearing chaos, several justices said states may require members of the Electoral College to vote for the presidential candidates they had promised to support.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: Delegates looking at an interactive Electoral College map at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia in 2016.

item.title: Coronavirus Wrecked Tesla’s Momentum and Elon Musk Is Furious
item.description: Mr. Musk opened his California factory this week in defiance of local orders. He has also criticized the response to the pandemic as “dumb” and “fascist.”
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: The employee parking lot at Tesla’s factory in Fremont, Calif., was full on Tuesday after Elon Musk said the plant would restart in violation of a county order.

item.title: Officials in Arkansas Put Travis McCready Concert in Doubt
item.description: Arkansas officials said they would not approve the planned Friday concert by Travis McCready as the promoters announced a second show in nearby Missouri.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley
item.media:credit: Terry Wyatt/Getty Images For Pilgrimage Music & Cultural Festival
item.media:description: Travis McCready, who was slated to perform in a concert in Arkansas on Friday, three days before the state’s reopening for venues with audiences of fewer than 50 people.

item.title: Paul Manafort, Trump's Ex-Campaign Manager, Released from Prison
item.description: Paul Manafort, who had been serving a seven-and-a-half-year sentence in Pennsylvania for fraud, is among the prisoners released over the spreading coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Paul Manafort, President Trump’s former campaign manager, arriving at an arraignment hearing last year.

item.title: Low-Tech Way to Help Some Covid Patients: Flip Them Over
item.description: Turning ventilated patients onto their stomachs, called proning, helps them by opening their lungs. Now doctors are testing to see if it can keep others off ventilators altogether.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Lyndon French for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Sara Hanif Mirza checking on a patient who was proned at Rush University Medical Center in Chicago.

item.title: As Hunger Spreads With Coronavirus Pandemic, Government Takes Timid Steps
item.description: The Trump administration has taken some steps to address spreading hunger during the economic crisis, but it has shied away from expanding programs that could provide more immediate relief.
item.dc:creator: Lola Fadulu
item.media:credit: William Widmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers at a food drive in New Orleans.

item.title: Venezuelan Oil Company Sues Miami Ex-Congressman Over $50 Million Deal
item.description: Former Representative David Rivera, a strident anti-communist, was quietly consulting for President Nicolás Maduro’s socialist government. He produced five pages of reports, the lawsuit said.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Bill Clark/CQ Roll Call, via Associated Press Images
item.media:description: The American subsidiary of a Venezuelan oil company is suing former Representative David Rivera, Republican of Florida, for breach of contract.

item.title: El Dorado and Butte Counties Meet California Guidelines For Reopening
item.description: Wednesday: As California gradually allows businesses to reopen, officials say there still isn’t enough testing to move more quickly.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan and Brian X. Chen
item.media:description: Kenneth Lew wore a face mask while speaking on the phone at Crustacean restaurant in San Francisco on Tuesday.

item.title: On Politics: Fauci Speaks. Is the Government Listening?
item.description: A dire virus warning, and new wrangling over Trump’s tax returns: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Coronavirus, California, Michael Flynn: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: On Annexation, a Green Light Turns Yellow, Pompeo’s Visit to Israel Signals
item.description: Although the secretary of state took pains to avoid publicly addressing the issue, he seemed to caution Israel’s leadership against moving too quickly to annex occupied territory.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Kobi Gideon/Israel Government Press Office, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, right, with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Jerusalem on Wednesday. Neither publicly mentioned Israel’s annexation of occupied territory although analysts suspect it was a main point of the visit.

item.title: Joe Biden Has an Edge on Trump in the Polls. So Why Are Democrats Worried?
item.description: The former vice president has unified the party and is leading in the polls. But some Democrats say he faces familiar challenges, including slow decision-making and flaws in his digital operation.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck, Lisa Lerer, Shane Goldmacher and Alexander Burns
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. at a campaign event in Sumter, S.C., in February.

item.title: What Pandemic Scams Are People Falling For
item.description: Fraudsters see opportunities to target us in these uncertain times. Here are their most popular schemes and how we can protect ourselves.
item.dc:creator: Brian X. Chen
